Hi Nile! Love your videos. I also used to do chemical experiments at home, and watching your videos make me want to pick up on chemistry again.
Anyway, this video reminds me of a synthesys I also did at home, only I made Orange II. Pretty much the same reaction, only sulfanilic acid is used instead of p-nitroaniline.
I did not have nitrite at that moment, so I made some myself by heating some potassium nitrate in a test tube. And I managed to get my hands on some 1-naphtol instead of 2-naphtol. I gave it a try anyway and it worked!..still surpirised :-)

Thanks for this cool video. It reminded me of the dyes used in colour photography back in those days. The reduction of silver grain by the developer would couple to an unsoluble dye by its oxydation product. The magenta layer of negative film was special in that it contained already a yellow dye with an azo bound which would be split on exposed areas during development and then becomes magenta. This was a cool trick to compensate for side lobe absorptions of the cyan layer (or yellow layer don't remember ) when the negative gets enlarged or printed to positive paper or film. Back in these days I was a hobby fotographer and did alot of experimentation in the darkroom but also catched interest in the associated chemistry. But unlike you I am not a chemist. I'm just admiring your interesting derivations. Keep up the good work!
Regards Lutz

When I saw the yellow color coming through it reminded me of an experiment I tried years ago. I had a couple of chunks of pure chromium and submerged them in magnesium sulfate. With the chromium pieces sticking out of the solution I touched the negative terminal of a battery to one piece and the positive to another piece. The solution started turning bright yellow! Just having a wick from top to bottom in a terrarium could possibly equalise the salts to some degree by diffusion as long as the entire length stayed wet which I'm guessing it would in 100% humidity.
You would probably have to arrange it so that downcoming condensed water could not soak in from the top and wash the salts back down, which may be difficult? I don't think long distance diffusion is fast enough to beat the condensation circulation.
A tiny bimetallic strip that would squeeze a drop from the top of the wick once a day could work, might need it to have a snap action though, not really sure how else to do it. Starting to sound pretty unreliable...

There is a very easy way to dye parts of a fabric without dying other parts. You use melted paraffin wax as a resist on the raw fabric. You then dye and wash the sheet using a shallow pan since you won't be able to crumple it up like normal fabric. You then sandwich the sheet between many sheets of newspaper and use an iron to draw the wax into the paper and off of your sheet. Final removal of the wax is done by rinsing the sheet in boiling water.
